EMERGENCY RESPONSE

Epsilyte will immediately contact external resources to respond to major leaks, or spills. See Appendix A Emergency Contact Phone List.
If there is a major leak or spill of pentane, the emergency alarm system is activated, or in the event of an alert notice through the paging system, all employees are to respond in a defensive fashion and evacuate as follows: 
1. 	 Everyone should immediately stop whatever they are doing, remain calm and leave their work area. If possible, turn off all electrical equipment before leaving the work area. Under all circumstances, remember that safety of life is the first concern.  The Emergency pentane Shutoff I-7 must be activated if at all possible.  
2.	It is the responsibility of the shift supervisor for each area to see that all employees in their area leave the building promptly and safely. All employees should exit the building by way of the nearest facility exit away from the pentane storage tanks. Employees should move to the Far East end of the facility unless directed to a different location by the shift supervisor based on wind direction. Response and clean up should be done by the local Fire Department or other authorized local, state or federal authorities. Check to ensure the public and appropriate authorities have been notified.

Passive mitigation considerations are as follows:

The vessels at Epsilyte are 3 bullet-style vessels operating at atmospheric pressure.  The vessels are carbon steel, butt welded construction and painted with paint that is resistant to outdoor elements. The piping and valves used for the movement of the pentane meet the specifications of standardized gas/fluid containment.  An external engineering contractor was used for the inspection of the vessels and system upon initial installation. 

Administrative controls and engineering controls are implemented to reduce the hazard associated with the pentane system.  Administrative controls consist of training and inspections. 
of the system.  Engineering controls consist of pressure relief valves, routine maintenance, and dike walls.

The worst-case estimated quantity released is 188,415 lbs of liquid pentane, released to the diked containment area.  This is determined by taking 35,550 gallons (largest tank) and multiplying it by 5.3 (lbs./gal of pentane).  The rate of pentane vapor evaporation is 1,260 lbs. per minute (derived from RMP*Comp). 

  The release quantity of the worst-case scenario is based on the complete loss of containment of a single pentane storage tank.

The consequence is a pool fire with an affected distance endpoint of 0.02 miles, which is entirely within the subject property.  RMP*Comp, a release duration of 10 minutes and a rate of 25 lbs. per minute were used.   This scenario was selected because it is the most likely occurrence, resulting in emergency measures.

FLAMMABLE: WORST CASE

	The determination of the worst-case scenario was conducted using liquid Isopentane (CAS 78-78-4) using RMP*Comp. This assessment determined that the distance to a public receptor is within the range of the impact area. There are a number of public and private businesses located within 0.2 mile of the tank storage location.  There are no residential properties, institutions, parks or recreational areas, schools, or environmental receptors within the affected distance.  There are two businesses to the North across Statler Road and one business to the South within the affected distance. Google Earth was used to derive Latitude and Longitude coordinates for Polysource, Inc.  The coordinates for the tanks are Latitude: 40.13564 and Longitude -84.22545.

The release prevention and emergency response policies of Polysource LLC dba Epsilyte (Epsilyte). are intended to protect its employees as well as the community it serves from the dangers associated with Iso-pentane and pentane blends, as well as comply with applicable federal and state regulations. 
 
	Epsilyte is in Piqua, Ohio and is a manufacturer of Expandable Polystyrene (EPS).  During the manufacturing process of EPS, pentanes are used as a blowing agent and are an essential key component to the product.  Due to the storage of pentanes in a quantity over the threshold limit of 10,000 lbs., Epsilyte is subject to compliance with the EPA Risk Management Program.

  The release rate of the worst-case scenario is based on a large hole in the vessel and the loss of approximately 189 gallons a minute and duration of 10 minutes. Ten minutes is based on the time it would take to notice a rapid drop in the pentane pressure.  The alternative release scenario is a smaller size hole that would dissipate 25 lbs. per minute.  Again, the duration of 10 minutes is used based on the time it would take to notice the drop in pressure.  
  
	Epsilyte is following OSHA PSM and EPA RMP level 3. The Prevention Program section of this document includes: PHA, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Management of Change, Pre-Start Up, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, Employee Participation, Hot Work Permit, and Contractor Safety Procedures. PSM and RCMS documents are used where those regulations call for the same compliance documentation as RMP to eliminate confusion and redundancy. Those documents include but not limited to:

1.	MOC (PSM)
2.	PSSR (PSM)

4.	Hot Work Permitting (RCMS)
5.	Contractor Safety (RCMS)
